reporting-org.narrative: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands

description.narrative: Low scale conflict between Government security forces and RENAMO armed elements flared up again in Mozambique in October 2012, restarting a conflict between the two parties, lingering ever since the end of the civil war in 1992. This conflict has disrupted the livelihoods of families living in the conflict affected areas, especially in central Mozambique, one of the focus regions of the NL development programme. These families depend on agriculture for both food consumption and income generation. Losing their agricultural production is detrimental to their well-being and food security. Under the mediation of the international community, negotiations between the conflicting parties led to the signing of the Maputo Accord for Peace and Reconciliation in 2019. Both parties have been committed to Disarmament, Demobilization and socioeconomic Reintegration (DDR) of RENAMO ex-combatants. In this regard, UNOPS established a 2-year project "Support to Implementation of the Maputo Accord for Peace and Reconciliation", focusing on social reinsertion and economic reintegration of ex-combatants. The project is funded through a Multi-Donor Trust Fund (MDTF) and implemented by the Peace Process Support Secretariat, led by the UNSG personal envoy, Mirko Manzoni. Support is required for 5.221 RENAMO ex-combatants and their families (in total 26.105 people), to enable them to leave their current positions and return to their communities. The ex-combatants will receive a one-off reinsertion package, made up of kit of basic personal and household essentials as well as an initial instalment of a '12-month reinsertion transition pay­ ment' immediately upon demobilisation. The kits will be differ­ entiated for men and women. Each ex-combatant will have a bank account for subsequent reinsertion transition instalments. Given the agricultural background of the ex-combatants, the economic reintegration will focus mostly on farming as a business. The ex-combatants and their dependents will benefit from improved agricultural inputs through seed vouchers and technical assistance to support them in setting-up and managing their farms. In addition to contributing directly to the food security situation of the ex-combatants and their families, this activity will help create a stable and safe environment in which development programmes, supported by NL and other donors, and public and private investments can be implemented in a more sdble environment.
